author: Grimms
text: A poor woodman sat in his cottage one night, smoking his pipe by the fireside, while his wife sat by his side spinning.

author: Grimms
text: "How lonely it is, wife," said he, as he puffed out a long curl of smoke, "for you and me to sit here by ourselves, without any children to play about and amuse us while other people seem so happy and merry with their children!"

author: Grimms
text: "What you say is very true," said the wife, sighing, and turning round her wheel; "how happy should I be if I had but one child!

author: Grimms
text: If it were ever so small--nay, if it were no bigger than my thumb--I should be very happy, and love it dearly."

author: Grimms
text: Now--odd as you may think it--it came to pass that this good woman"s wish was fulfilled, just in the very way she had wished it; for, not long afterwards, she had a little boy, who was quite healthy and strong, but was not much bigger than my thumb.

author: Grimms
text: So they said, "Well, we cannot say we have not got what we wished for, and, little as he is, we will love him dearly."

author: Grimms
text: And they called him Thomas Thumb.

author: Grimms
text: They gave him plenty of food, yet for all they could do he never grew bigger, but kept just the same size as he had been when he was born.

author: Grimms
text: Still, his eyes were sharp and sparkling, and he soon showed himself to be a clever little fellow, who always knew well what he was about.

author: Grimms
text: One day, as the woodman was getting ready to go into the wood to cut fuel, he said, "I wish I had someone to bring the cart after me, for I want to make haste."

author: Grimms
text: "Oh, father," cried Tom, "I will take care of that; the cart shall be in the wood by the time you want it."

author: Grimms
text: Then the woodman laughed, and said, "How can that be? you cannot reach up to the horse"s bridle."

author: Grimms
text: "Never mind that, father," said Tom; "if my mother will only harness the horse, I will get into his ear and tell him which way to go."

author: Grimms
text: "Well," said the father, "we will try for once."

author: Grimms
text: When the time came the mother harnessed the horse to the cart, and put Tom into his ear; and as he sat there the little man told the beast how to go, crying out, "Go on!" and "Stop!" as he wanted: and thus the horse went on just as well as if the woodman had driven it himself into the wood.

author: Grimms
text: It happened that as the horse was going a little too fast, and Tom was calling out, "Gently! gently!" two strangers came up.

author: Grimms
text: "What an odd thing that is!" said one: "there is a cart going along, and I hear a carter talking to the horse, but yet I can see no one."

author: Grimms
text: "That is queer, indeed," said the other; "let us follow the cart, and see where it goes."

author: Grimms
text: So they went on into the wood, till at last they came to the place where the woodman was.

author: Grimms
text: Then Tom Thumb, seeing his father, cried out, "See, father, here I am with the cart, all right and safe! now take me down!"

author: Grimms
text: So his father took hold of the horse with one hand, and with the other took his son out of the horse"s ear, and put him down upon a straw, where he sat as merry as you please.

author: Grimms
text: The two strangers were all this time looking on, and did not know what to say for wonder.

author: Grimms
text: At last one took the other aside, and said, "That little urchin will make our fortune, if we can get him, and carry him about from town to town as a show; we must buy him."

author: Grimms
text: So they went up to the woodman, and asked him what he would take for the little man.

author: Grimms
text: "He will be better off," said they, "with us than with you."

author: Grimms
text: "I won"t sell him at all," said the father; "my own flesh and blood is dearer to me than all the silver and gold in the world."

author: Grimms
text: But Tom, hearing of the bargain they wanted to make, crept up his father"s coat to his shoulder and whispered in his ear, "Take the money, father, and let them have me; I"ll soon come back to you."

author: Grimms
text: So the woodman at last said he would sell Tom to the strangers for a large piece of gold, and they paid the price.

author: Grimms
text: "Where would you like to sit?" said one of them.

author: Grimms
text: "Oh, put me on the rim of your hat; that will be a nice gallery for me; I can walk about there and see the country as we go along."

author: Grimms
text: So they did as he wished; and when Tom had taken leave of his father they took him away with them.

author: Grimms
text: They journeyed on till it began to be dusky, and then the little man said, "Let me get down, I"m tired."

author: Grimms
text: So the man took off his hat, and put him down on a clod of earth, in a ploughed field by the side of the road.

author: Grimms
text: But Tom ran about amongst the furrows, and at last slipped into an old mouse-hole.

author: Grimms
text: "Good night, my masters!" said he, "I"m off! mind and look sharp after me the next time."

author: Grimms
text: Then they ran at once to the place, and poked the ends of their sticks into the mouse-hole, but all in vain; Tom only crawled farther and farther in; and at last it became quite dark, so that they were forced to go their way without their prize, as sulky as could be.

author: Grimms
text: When Tom found they were gone, he came out of his hiding-place.

author: Grimms
text: "What dangerous walking it is," said he, "in this ploughed field!

author: Grimms
text: If I were to fall from one of these great clods, I should undoubtedly break my neck."

author: Grimms
text: At last, by good luck, he found a large empty snail-shell.

author: Grimms
text: "This is lucky," said he, "I can sleep here very well"; and in he crept.

author: Grimms
text: Just as he was falling asleep, he heard two men passing by, chatting together; and one said to the other, "How can we rob that rich parson"s house of his silver and gold?"

author: Grimms
text: "I"ll tell you!" cried Tom.

author: Grimms
text: "What noise was that?" said the thief, frightened; "I"m sure I heard someone speak."

author: Grimms
text: They stood still listening, and Tom said, "Take me with you, and I"ll soon show you how to get the parson"s money."

author: Grimms
text: "But where are you?" said they.

author: Grimms
text: "Look about on the ground," answered he, "and listen where the sound comes from."

author: Grimms
text: At last the thieves found him out, and lifted him up in their hands.

author: Grimms
text: "You little urchin!" they said, "what can you do for us?"

author: Grimms
text: "Why, I can get between the iron window-bars of the parson"s house, and throw you out whatever you want."

author: Grimms
text: "That"s a good thought," said the thieves; "come along, we shall see what you can do."

author: Grimms
text: When they came to the parson"s house, Tom slipped through the windowbars into the room, and then called out as loud as he could bawl, "Will you have all that is here?"

author: Grimms
text: At this the thieves were frightened, and said, "Softly, softly!

author: Grimms
text: Speak low, that you may not awaken anybody."

author: Grimms
text: But Tom seemed as if he did not understand them, and bawled out again, "How much will you have?

author: Grimms
text: Shall I throw it all out?"

author: Grimms
text: Now the cook lay in the next room; and hearing a noise she raised herself up in her bed and listened.

author: Grimms
text: Meantime the thieves were frightened, and ran off a little way; but at last they plucked up their hearts, and said, "The little urchin is only trying to make fools of us."

author: Grimms
text: So they came back and whispered softly to him, saying, "Now let us have no more of your roguish jokes; but throw us out some of the money."

author: Grimms
text: Then Tom called out as loud as he could, "Very well! hold your hands! here it comes."

author: Grimms
text: The cook heard this quite plain, so she sprang out of bed, and ran to open the door.

author: Grimms
text: The thieves ran off as if a wolf was at their tails: and the maid, having groped about and found nothing, went away for a light.

author: Grimms
text: By the time she came back, Tom had slipped off into the barn; and when she had looked about and searched every hole and corner, and found nobody, she went to bed, thinking she must have been dreaming with her eyes open.

author: Grimms
text: The little man crawled about in the hay-loft, and at last found a snug place to finish his night"s rest in; so he laid himself down, meaning to sleep till daylight, and then find his way home to his father and mother.

author: Grimms
text: But alas! how woefully he was undone! what crosses and sorrows happen to us all in this world!

author: Grimms
text: The cook got up early, before daybreak, to feed the cows; and going straight to the hay-loft, carried away a large bundle of hay, with the little man in the middle of it, fast asleep.

author: Grimms
text: He still, however, slept on, and did not awake till he found himself in the mouth of the cow; for the cook had put the hay into the cow"s rick, and the cow had taken Tom up in a mouthful of it.

author: Grimms
text: "Good lack-a-day!" said he, "how came I to tumble into the mill?"

author: Grimms
text: But he soon found out where he really was; and was forced to have all his wits about him, that he might not get between the cow"s teeth, and so be crushed to death.

author: Grimms
text: At last down he went into her stomach.

author: Grimms
text: "It is rather dark," said he; "they forgot to build windows in this room to let the sun in; a candle would be no bad thing."

author: Grimms
text: Though he made the best of his bad luck, he did not like his quarters at all; and the worst of it was, that more and more hay was always coming down, and the space left for him became smaller and smaller.

author: Grimms
text: At last he cried out as loud as he could, "Don"t bring me any more hay!

author: Grimms
text: Don"t bring me any more hay!"

author: Grimms
text: The maid happened to be just then milking the cow; and hearing someone speak, but seeing nobody, and yet being quite sure it was the same voice that she had heard in the night, she was so frightened that she fell off her stool, and overset the milk-pail.

author: Grimms
text: As soon as she could pick herself up out of the dirt, she ran off as fast as she could to her master the parson, and said, "Sir, sir, the cow is talking!"

author: Grimms
text: But the parson said, "Woman, thou art surely mad!"

author: Grimms
text: However, he went with her into the cow-house, to try and see what was the matter.

author: Grimms
text: Scarcely had they set foot on the threshold, when Tom called out, "Don"t bring me any more hay!"

author: Grimms
text: Then the parson himself was frightened; and thinking the cow was surely bewitched, told his man to kill her on the spot.

author: Grimms
text: So the cow was killed, and cut up; and the stomach, in which Tom lay, was thrown out upon a dunghill.

author: Grimms
text: Tom soon set himself to work to get out, which was not a very easy task; but at last, just as he had made room to get his head out, fresh ill-luck befell him.

author: Grimms
text: A hungry wolf sprang out, and swallowed up the whole stomach, with Tom in it, at one gulp, and ran away.

author: Grimms
text: Tom, however, was still not disheartened; and thinking the wolf would not dislike having some chat with him as he was going along, he called out, "My good friend, I can show you a famous treat."

author: Grimms
text: "Where"s that?" said the wolf.

author: Grimms
text: "In such and such a house," said Tom, describing his own father"s house.

author: Grimms
text: "You can crawl through the drain into the kitchen and then into the pantry, and there you will find cakes, ham, beef, cold chicken, roast pig, apple-dumplings, and everything that your heart can wish."

author: Grimms
text: The wolf did not want to be asked twice; so that very night he went to the house and crawled through the drain into the kitchen, and then into the pantry, and ate and drank there to his heart"s content.

author: Grimms
text: As soon as he had had enough he wanted to get away; but he had eaten so much that he could not go out by the same way he came in.

author: Grimms
text: This was just what Tom had reckoned upon; and now he began to set up a great shout, making all the noise he could.

author: Grimms
text: "Will you be easy?" said the wolf; "you"ll awaken everybody in the house if you make such a clatter."

author: Grimms
text: "What"s that to me?" said the little man; "you have had your frolic, now I"ve a mind to be merry myself"; and he began, singing and shouting as loud as he could.

author: Grimms
text: The woodman and his wife, being awakened by the noise, peeped through a crack in the door; but when they saw a wolf was there, you may well suppose that they were sadly frightened; and the woodman ran for his axe, and gave his wife a scythe.

author: Grimms
text: "Do you stay behind," said the woodman, "and when I have knocked him on the head you must rip him up with the scythe."

author: Grimms
text: Tom heard all this, and cried out, "Father, father!

author: Grimms
text: I am here, the wolf has swallowed me."

author: Grimms
text: And his father said, "Heaven be praised! we have found our dear child again"; and he told his wife not to use the scythe for fear she should hurt him.

author: Grimms
text: Then he aimed a great blow, and struck the wolf on the head, and killed him on the spot! and when he was dead they cut open his body, and set Tommy free.

author: Grimms
text: "Ah!" said the father, "what fears we have had for you!"

author: Grimms
text: "Yes, father," answered he; "I have travelled all over the world, I think, in one way or other, since we parted; and now I am very glad to come home and get fresh air again."

author: Grimms
text: "Why, where have you been?" said his father.

author: Grimms
text: "I have been in a mouse-hole--and in a snail-shell--and down a cow"s throat-- and in the wolf"s belly; and yet here I am again, safe and sound."

author: Grimms
text: "Well," said they, "you are come back, and we will not sell you again for all the riches in the world."

author: Grimms
text: Then they hugged and kissed their dear little son, and gave him plenty to eat and drink, for he was very hungry; and then they fetched new clothes for him, for his old ones had been quite spoiled on his journey.

author: Grimms
text: So Master Thumb stayed at home with his father and mother, in peace; for though he had been so great a traveller, and had done and seen so many fine things, and was fond enough of telling the whole story, he always agreed that, after all, there"s no place like HOME!
